newsitem.title: USA: US personal bankruptcies may set new record-group.
newsitem.headline: US personal bankruptcies may set new record-group.

text.p: The number of Americans filing for personal bankruptcy is expected to reach an all-time high of one million in 1996, a banking group said.

"We are on a pace to have over one million personal bankruptcies filed this year for the first time in U.S. history," American Bankers Association chief economist James Chessen told the House Banking Committee.
Chessen also noted that rising U.S. consumer credit delinquencies have triggered concern in the industry, but he said they "do not pose a serious threat" to the financial condition of banks.
Consumer credit card delinquencies have climbed steadily over the past one-and-a-half years and the trend is likely to continue for the next quarter, the banking group predicted.
Delinquencies have reached a level previously seen only during recessions.
"Of course we are not in a recession now, which makes the current high level of credit card delinquencies more troublesome," Chessen said.
A Visa USA Inc. official, also testifying before Congress, urged lawmakers to "act decisively" to address issues raised by the wave of bankruptcy filings.

During the first half of 1996, personal bankruptcy filings in the United States jumped by 26 percent over the same period a year earlier. Bank credit card losses "will continue to grow unless problems with the Bankruptcy Code are addressed," said Kenneth Crone, vice president of risk management at VISA.
"Bankruptcy no longer appears to carry the social stigma it once did," making it far easier for consumers to wipe out their debt," Crone maintained.
